Graphical abstract Photocatalysis Minisci-type reactions involving carbon-centered radicals (CCRs) have emerged as a hot and significant topic in the field of organic synthesis chemistry. Herein, we present a nickel-vanadium nanoparticle anchored on carbon nitride catalyst (NiV-CN) and persulfate as a hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) precursor. This catalyst enables the photocatalytic Minisci-type CCR alkylation. The nickel-vanadium nanoparticles are synthesized via electrostatic attraction between [V10O28]6− anions and Ni(HCO3)2, with in situ self-assembly occurring during the hydrothermal process. In the model reaction of 4-methylquinoline with cyclohexane, the NiV-CN catalyst showed high stability, without significant loss its catalytic activity after three cycles. The CCRs was extended to cycloalkanes, adamantanes, and cyclic ethers, which react with quinoline, isoquinoline, and benzothiazole to provide the corresponding products in moderate to excellent yields. Mechanism studies indicate that nickel-vanadium nanoparticles play a crucial role in the formation process of carbon-centered radicals by activating the persulfate precursor into sulfate radicals under visible-light irradiation. Keywords Decavanadate Photocatalysis Carbon nitride Carbon-centered radicals (CCRs) Dual-metal ions Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Photocatalysis Minisci-type reactions involving carbon-centered radicals (CCRs) have emerged as a hot and significant topic in the field of organic synthesis chemistry [1–3]. As a promising approach for organic synthesis, the Minisci-type alkylation represents a powerful tool for generating valuable functional aromatic heterocyclic through the addition of alkyl CCR to electron-deficient heterocyclic [4,5]. The most vital step in Minisci-type alkylation is to generate CCRs [6–19], and substantial endeavors have been made to identify suitable alkyl CCRs precursors, such as alkyl halides [20–22], alkyl alcohols [7,23,24], aliphatic ethers [13,25], carboxylic acids [26–28], aldehydes [12,19,20], and among others [6,11,18,29–34]. Among these precursors, cyclic alkanes, as environmentally benign alkyl CCRs precursors, have garnered significant attention owing to their ubiquity, cost-effectiveness, and high atom and step economy [9,14,35–37], positioning them as the preferred alkylation reagents. Extensive investigations have demonstrated that activated alkanes, such as cyclic ethers, can be activated by active oxygen species to form CCRs [13,38,39]. This phenomenon can be ascribed to the diminished electron cloud density of carbon resulting from the attraction exerted by ortho oxygen atoms, thereby facilitating the cleavage of the C–H bond. Considering possession of a stereostructure analogous to methane, unactivated alkanes such as cyclohexane exhibit higher bond dissociation energies (BDEs) compared to cyclic ethers (cyclohexane C6H11-H 416.3 kJ/mol, tetrahydrofuran α-H 384.9 kJ/mol) [40]. Hence, unactivated alkanes exhibit stability and recalcitrance in the formation of CCRs. Despite the significant progress in traditional methods, it is still desirable to develop a new photocatalysis system for investigating the conversion of unactivated alkanes to CCRs under mild conditions. In consideration of the inherent stability of the cyclohexane, recent endeavors have been directed toward the design of photocatalytic systems capable of activating cyclohexane for the formation of alkyl CCRs, thereby enabling photocatalytic Minisci-type alkylation reactions [9,14,35,36,41]. Recently, the utilization of non-noble metal FeCl3/LiCl photocatalytic systems for the activation of cyclohexane to alkyl CCRs via chlorine radical-mediated HAT has been explored (Table 1 ) [42]. However, the current situation necessitates the utilization of high-energy UV light. Consequently, the development of visible light-induced efficient photocatalysis for Minisci-type alkylation reactions utilizing non-noble metal photocatalysts emerges as a new trend. A diverse array of non-noble metal photocatalysts have emerged, including metal porphyrins [43–48], graphitic carbon nitride [49–54], and metal organic framework [47,55,56], etc. Among them, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) [57–63] has a similar structure to graphene, the sp2 hybridized CN atoms of g-C3N4 form a highly delocalized π-conjugated system, which enables it to absorb photons in visible region, exhibiting excellent photocatalysis performance in the field of hydrogen production [64–67] and organic transformation [68–72]. Interestingly, organic molecule and cyanamide functionalized g-C3N4 has also demonstrated the ability to activate activated alkanes, such as cyclic ethers, to alkyl CCRs in the presence of oxygen [13,73]. However, unactivated alkanes, for instance, cyclohexane, has not presented in these situations. The reason may be that the localized electrons, resulting from the connection of nitrogen between heptazine rings, suppress the photogenerated carrier (electron and hole) separation efficiency. Investigations reveal that the incorporation of metal or bimetallic ion active sites for the modification of carbon nitride facilitates photogenerated charge carrier separation, leading to an enhancement in quantum efficiency [74–83]. More importantly, the bimetallic ion active sites exhibit the power ability to promote specific molecule transformation [78–84]. And the N and O atoms on the surface of g-C3N4 can coordinate with metal ions, serving as the visible-light-responsive support material, avoiding metal aggregation and improving the activity of the catalyst. In addition, the mechanism of bimetallic active sites activating unactivated alkanes to form CCRs under specific conditions remains elusive. It is of great significance to investigate the relationship between bimetallic active sites and photocatalysis performance. Given the paramount importance of bimetallic metal sites and the formation mechanism of CCRs, the capacity of the metal to directly or indirectly activate C–H bond in alkanes ought to be prioritized. As a member of polyoxometalates (POMs), decavanadate ([V10O28]6−) has a similar structure to decatungstate ([W10O32]4−), and its high-valence V (+5) atom exhibits reversible multi-electron transfer characteristics, demonstrating high photocatalytic performance [85–88]. Despite the power of decatungstate in photocatalysis under ultraviolet (UV) light irradiation, the advantage of decavanadate lies in its visible light absorption compared to decatungstate [87]. Research shows that the introduction of noble metals in decavanadate catalytic system exhibits efficient C–H bond activation ability [89,90]. Based on the similarity in structure between non-noble metals and noble metals, non-noble metals enable the substitution of noble metals and cooperation with decavanadate to achieve catalytic activation of C–H bonds. As a kind of non-noble metal, nickel ion has a d-orbital valence state with unfilled electrons, which has attracted much attention due to its high ability in photocatalytic organic synthesis [91]. At the same time, introducing the nickel ion in the complex materials via coordination with N or O in g-C3N4 and [V10O28]6− mitigated the deactivation of highly active nickel species. Therefore, it can be predicted that the integration of nickel ions with decavanadate anchored on graphite carbon nitride enables the photocatalytic generation of CCRs and the realization of Minisci-type alkylation. Herein, a simple hydrothermal synthesis method was employed to fabricate carbon nitride-supported nickel-vanadium (NiV) nanoparticles for photocatalytic activation of C–H bonds to form CCRs and realize the Minisci-type alkylation. In the model reaction of 4-methylquinoline with cyclohexane, alkyl CCRs was formed with the help of sulfate radical, which were induced by the NiV-CN catalyst, through a HAT mechanism. The substrate tolerance of the reaction was investigated with quinoline, isoquinoline, benzothiazole, cycloalkane and adamantane as substrates, and up to 99 % and 94 % yields were obtained under Xe lamp and blue LED (450 nm) irradiation, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Isoquinoline, 4-bromoisoquinoline, 4-methylquinoline, 2-chloroquinoline, 4-chloroquinoline, benzothiazole, cyclopentane, cyclohexane, cycloheptane, amantadane, tetrahydrofuran, tetrahydropyran, 1, 4-dioxane were purchased from Energy Chemical. Ethanol and hydrochloric acid (36.0–38.0 wt% in water) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Instrumentation Morphologies and microstructures of the catalysts were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Hitachi-S4800). The phase purity of as-obtained catalysts was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) recorded on a SmartLab 9 kW (Rigaku, Cu Kα λ = 1.5406 Å). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was collected with KBr-pressed pellets on a Nicolet 6700-IR spectrophotometer in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded on a Quadrasorb SI automated surface area and pore size analyzer (Quantachrome). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) profiles and chemical state analysis were performed by ESCALAB Xi + X-ray photoelectron spectrometer using Al Kα X-ray as the excitation source. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) were recorded on an Agilent Cary 300 (BaSO4 as a standard). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) experiments were performed on a Bruker A300 EPR spectrometer under the following conditions: center field 3380 Gs, sweep width 500 Gs, microwave frequency 10 mW, modulation amplitude 2.00 Gs, and sweeping time 60 s. Decay curves of the as-fabricated products were obtained on an FLS-1000 fluorescence lifetime spectrophotometer under the excitation of a hydrogen flash lamp with a wavelength of 350 nm. Column chromatography was performed on silica gel (200–400 mesh). The NMR spectra were taken with a Bruker 500 spectrometer at 500 MHz (1H) using CDCl3 as the solvent with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard. The high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) was recorded on Thermo Scientific QE plus. 2.3 Preparation of graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) The preparation of g-C3N4 was carried out according to previously established protocol. Firstly, 20 g urea was placed into a crucible with a cover and subjected to pyrolysis at 550 °C for three hours in a muffle furnace under ambient pressure in air. Subsequently, the furnace was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting products were rinsed with 95 % alcohol and deionized (DI) water, collected by filtration, and dried at 80 °C. 2.4 Preparation of vanadium oxygen cluster ([(n-C4H9)4N]3[V10O28H3], abbreviated as {V10O28}) First, 15.0 g of Na3VO4 was dissolved in 110 mL of deionized water. Then, 71 mL of HCl (3 mol/L) was added dropwise at a rate of two drops per second under rapid stirring. As the acid was added, the color of the solution changed from colorless to orange. Next, a solution of tetrabutylammonium bromide (60 mL, 1 g/mL) was added in portions of 2 mL each, stirred for an additional 15 mins, and filtered to obtain an orange-yellow precipitate. The precipitate was washed with water, ethanol, and ether, and then dried for 12 h. The crude product was dissolved in 150 mL of acetonitrile, stirred for 10 mins, and then 300 mL of anhydrous ether was added. After slowly evaporating, a deep orange precipitate was obtained. The precipitate was collected, washed with 100 mL of anhydrous ether, and vacuum-dried for 1 h to obtain a yellow-orange solid. 2.5 Preparation of nickel-vanadium nanoparticle modified carbon nitride (NiV-CN) First, 1.0 g of {V10O28}, 1.0 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and 4.0 g of g-C3N4 were added to 30 mL deionized water. Then, the mixture was subjected to ultrasonic treatment for 1 h, followed by stirring for 24 h. Afterward, the solution was transferred to a 50 mL polytetrafluoroethylene-lined reactor and placed in a drying oven, undergoing hydrothermally treated at 180° C for 2 h. After the reaction, the reaction kettle was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, and the supernatant was poured out. The precipitate was centrifuged and washed several times with deionized water and ethanol, then placed in a vacuum drying oven at 60° C for 12 h. The pale-yellow powder product is labeled as NiV-CN. 2.6 The general process for the photocatalytic Minisci-type alkylation In a 10 mL quartz reaction vessel, 4-methylquinoline (0.1 mmol), cyclohexane (4 mmol, 40 equiv.), acetonitrile (2 mL), photocatalyst NiV-CN (2 mg), HCl (1.5 equiv.), and K2S2O8 (0.2 mmol, 2 equiv.) were added. Stirring was performed at room temperature under light irradiation, with a small fan present, and using TLC to monitor the reaction. After the reaction was completed, the catalyst was centrifuged and washed with deionized water and acetonitrile for the next catalytic cycle. The solution was washed with saturated sodium bicarbonate and saturated brine, and dried with anhydrous magnesium sulfate. The product was purified by column chromatography separation method and the yield was calculated. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristic of catalyst The pale-yellow powder of NiV-CN was successfully synthesized in a simple hydrothermal method as shown in Experimental 2.5, and subsequently underwent comprehensive characterization via a range of spectroscopic methods. The surface morphology of NiV-CN material was characterized by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 1 ). As shown in Fig. 1A, the SEM image reveals that nanoparticles (with diameters < 100 nm) are attached to the carbon nitride. This can be more clearly observed in the TEM images (Fig. 1B-D). Moreover, the g-C3N4 exhibits a folded lamellar structure, which coincides with the SEM image shown in Fig. 1A. The lattice fringes of 0.119 and 0.239 nm correspond to the (550) and (321) lattice planes of Ni(HCO3)2 (Fig. 1E1, E2). Furthermore, energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy elemental mapping images further confirm that Ni and V elements are only present in the nanoparticles, while the O element distribution in the nanoparticles is higher than on the plane, due to the high O ratio in {V10O28}. Additionally, the C and N elements have a uniform distribution throughout the NiV-CN material. The above results confirmed that the nickel-vanadium nanoparticles are attached to the carbon nitride. The crystalline phase, chemical composition, and chemical bond state of NiV-CN material was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 2 A-B, and Figure S3 shows the PXRD of the as-prepared NiV-CN composite. In the PXRD pattern, we found that only the characteristic broad peak of 27.4° in g-C3N4 can be found in NiV-CN (Fig. S3 A). Considering that NiV-CN is hydrothermally synthesized at 180 ℃ and hydrothermal treatment can change the crystal structure of the material, we treated {V10O28} and g-C3N4 under the same hydrothermal conditions, which were abbreviated as {V10O28}-180 and g-C3N4-180, respectively. Because nickel nitrate did not form any solid under the same hydrothermal conditions, there was no corresponding Ni-180 as a comparison (Fig. S3B). We compared the changes of {V10O28} and g-C3N4 before and after hydrothermal treatment in detail. We found that the crystallinity of g-C3N4-180 improved, whereas the peak intensity of {V10O28}-180 decreased after hydrothermal treatment (Fig. S3C-D). In the PXRD pattern, we can clearly see the existence of g-C3N4-180 in NiV-CN composite (Fig. 2A, Fig. S3F). In the PXRD pattern of the NiV-CN composite, the diffraction peaks are indexed to match Ni(HCO3)2 (PDF#97–019-6120), indicating Ni(HCO3)2 is formed from Ni(NO3)2 under hydrothermal conditions described in the Experimental 2.5 (Fig. 2A, Fig. S3E). In the PXRD pattern of the NiV-CN composite, the diffraction peaks are not found to match {V10O28}-180. It may be due to the fact that the diffraction peak of {V10O28}-180 is suppressed by the diffraction peak of g-C3N4-180 and Ni(HCO3)2 (Fig. S3B). The functional groups of NiV-CN composite were characterized by FTIR. In accordance with the PXRD analysis, we have also found that the FTIR spectra of the raw materials {V10O28} and g-C3N4 do not match well in the NiV-CN composite (Fig. S2A). While, by carefully analyzing the infrared spectra of {V10O28}-180, g-C3N4-180 and NiV-CN, we found that the diffraction peaks of g-C3N4-180 correspond well with those in NiV-CN. Almost no diffraction peak of {V10O28}-180 is observed (Fig. S2B). In addition, as shown in Fig. 2B, after carefully comparing the PXRD peaks of {V10O28} and {V10O28}-180, we found that only the peak at 7.1° in {V10O28} can be found in {V10O28}-180. Other peaks in {V10O28} exhibit a certain degree of leftward shift, which is likely caused by changes in the lattice or structural distortions, under hydrothermal conditions. In the FTIR spectra of g-C3N4 and g-C3N4-180, the stretching vibration of O–H and N–H peak in 3384, 3216, and 3052 cm−1 become stronger in g-C3N4-180, indicating the O–H or N–H bond increased through hydrothermal treatment. The characteristic stretching vibration of C-N heterocycles from 1200 to 1600 cm−1 and there are also some differences in the peak at 1318 and 1236 cm−1. In addition, the characteristic peak of triazine units at approximately 800 cm−1 with a slight red shift to 771 cm−1 (Fig. S2C). The results indicate that the structure of g-C3N4 has undergone modifications following hydrothermal treatment, which is consistent with the results of PXRD. As shown in Fig. 2C or Fig. S2D, the typical peaks for {V10O28} at 1000 and 961 cm−1 belongs to the stretching vibration of the terminal V = O bands. The peaks at 851, 778, 753 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric vibrations of the bridging V-O-V segments. The peaks at 612, 581 cm−1 belongs to the symmetric vibration of V-O-V. In the IR spectra of {V10O28}-180, the stretching vibration of the terminal V = O bands at 1004, 957. The asymmetric vibrations of the bridging V-O-V segments at 846, 775, 744. The symmetric vibration of V-O-V segments at 577. After carefully comparing the IR spectra of {V10O28} and {V10O28}-180, we found that the IR experimental data of {V10O28} and {V10O28}-180 were very similar. The preliminary results indicate that the structure of {V10O28} after hydrothermal treatment did not undergo complete structural collapse or destruction, despite being accompanied by peak shifts and decreased absorption. The chemical states of the elements in the NiV-CN composite were characterized by XPS. As shown in Figure S7, the XPS survey spectra of NiV-CN reveal the presence of C, N, O, Ni, and V elements. In the C 1 s XPS spectrum of the NiV-CN composite, the binding energies located at 288.1 eV and 284.8 eV correspond to the N = C-N bond and the C–C bond, respectively (Fig. 2D). In the N 1 s XPS spectrum, the binding energy at 400.3 eV, 399.1 eV, and 398.2 eV corresponds to C-N–H, N-C3, and C = N-C, respectively (Fig. 2E). In the O 1 s XPS spectrum, two characteristic peaks were fitted at 531.2 eV and 529.7 eV, which are attributed to C = O and V-O, respectively (Fig. 2F). In the Ni 2p XPS spectrum, binding energies of 861.6 and 855.5 eV correspond to Ni 2p3/2, while 879.7 and 873.3 eV are attributed to Ni 2p1/2, indicating the presence of Ni(HCO3)2 (Fig. 2G) [92]. The V 2p XPS spectrum of {V10O28} reveals that the binding energies at 516.8 and 515.3 eV correspond to V 2p3/2, while those at 524.4 and 523.3 eV correspond to V 2p1/2. This indicates that the vanadium centers within the cluster are primarily in the VV oxidation state, as evidenced by the peaks at 516.8 eV and 524.4 eV. Additionally, a small amount of VIV oxidation state can also be observed, marked by the peaks at 515.3 eV and 523.3 eV. The XPS data of the {V10O28}-180 sample exhibits VV oxidation state at 516.6 eV and 524.4 eV. While, the VIV oxidation state, present at 516.5 eV and 523.0 eV, is increased after hydrothermal treatment. Furthermore, the V 2p XPS spectrum of NiV-CN almost exclusively indicates the VV oxidation state at 516.4 eV and 524.1 eV (Fig. 2H). The results indicate that the chemical valence state of V in the NiV-CN composite remained and the stability of {V10O28} is maintained after hydrothermal treatment, which is consistent with the results of FTIR. The interactions between Ni(HCO3)2, {V10O28} and g-C3N4 were investigated using zeta potential measurements. As shown in Fig. 2I, the zeta potentials of g-C3N4, {V10O28}, V-CN and NiV-CN were measured to be 3.69 mV, −1.6 mV, −17.51 mV and −5.1 mV, respectively. These results indicate that the nanoparticles formed from Ni(HCO3)2 and {V10O28}, as well as the nanoparticles deposited on the g-C3N4, exhibit electrostatic interactions. The light absorption ability of NiV-CN composite was characterized by UV–Vis absorption spectroscopy. As shown in Figure S4, the absorption edge of g-C3N4 is at 450 nm. After anchored nickel-vanadium nanoparticle on g-C3N4, the absorption of NiV-CN composite is red-shifted to 600 nm, indicating the excellent capacity of visible light. According to the Tauc plot nalysis, the UV–Vis diffuse reflection bandgap diagram of NiV-CN is shown in Figure S5. The bandgap widths (Eg) of g-C3N4 were determined to be 3.03 eV, while the Eg value of the NiV-CN composite was decreased to 2.63 eV. The observed narrowing of the bandgap in the NiV-CN composite significantly contributed to an enhancement in its photocatalytic performance. The position of conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) of g-C3N4, V-CN, and NiV-CN composite were ascertained by VB-XPS and Tauc plot, as shown in Figure S5-6. The porosity and surface area of the powder were evaluated by measuring specific surface area (SSA). The SSA of g-C3N4 is 76.127 m2/g, while V-CN, and NiV-CN is slightly reduced to 2.196 m2/g and 13.231 m2/g, respectively (Figure S8). The results show that nickel-vanadium nanoparticles are filled in the g-C3N4, which reduces the specific surface area of NiV-CN material. At the same time, the thermal stability of the V-CN and NiV-CN composite were determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S9). According to the thermogravimetric curve, the composite NiV-CN began to decompose significantly at about 304° C, indicating that the composite had good thermal stability. In order to explore the photoelectrochemical properties of NiV-CN, a systematic photoelectrochemical test was carried out in 0.5 M K2SO4 electrolyte solution. As depicted in Fig. 3A, the incorporation of nickel-vanadium nanoparticles on carbon nitride results in a conspicuous enhancement in the photocurrent of the material. This augmentation signifies the high electron transfer efficiency exhibited by the NiV-CN catalyst under illumination. The enhanced photoelectric performance can be attributed to two pivotal factors. Firstly, the broadened visible light absorption of NiV-CN enables it to stimulate more electrons and improve the electron transfer efficiency. Secondly, nickel-vanadium nanoparticles can capture electrons from carbon nitride, promote the separation of photogenerated carriers, and thus enhance the photoelectric performance. The migration behavior and mobility of photogenerated carriers (electrons and holes) at the interface were detected by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). As shown in Fig. 3B, the NiV-CN composites exhibited a minimum arc radius compared to g-C3N4, which indicates that NiV-CN has more effective electron-hole separation and faster charge transfer, thus improving the photocatalytic performance. 3.2 Photocatalytic Minisci-type CCRs process In our initial investigation, we evaluated the photocatalytic Minisci-type CCRs performance of NiV-CN composites. As shown in Table 1, we selected the 4-methylquinoline (1a) reacted with cyclohexane (2b) as the representative substrates for the reaction. Utilizing NiV-CN as the catalyst and persulfate as a HAT precursor, the reaction was conducted under blue LED irradiation. After 15 h, the corresponding product 3b yielded 94 %, with 1.57 % apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) (as detailed in the Supporting Information). Table 1 presents a summary of various photocatalysis systems utilized for the Minisci-type reaction of 1a with 2a or 2b in the presence of catalysts and metal-free conditions, including precious metal iridium complex system (Ir(ppy)2(dtbbpy)PF6/K2SO8) [93], rare earth metal system (CeCl3/Bu4N+Cl−) [94], non-precious metal system (FeCl3/LiCl) [42], and hydrogen atom abstracteors (Diacetyl/DTBP [41], 2,6-lutidine N-oxide [95], TsNHMe/PIFA [96], and 2,2,2-trifluoro-1-(isoquinolin-1-yl)ethenone/Air (O2)) [14], and organic catalyst system (Mes-Acr+ClO4 -/(PhO)2P(O)OH) [36]. Compared to these photocatalytic systems, the NiV-CN was shown to be an effective catalyst for the visible light-induced Minisci-type CCRs process using persulfate as a HAT precursor under 450 nm LED irradiation. In contrast to the product yields of 3a and 3b reported in the literature, the approach presented herein demonstrates a valuable photocatalysis system. Inspired by the above results, our study began with the model reaction of 4-methylquinoline (1a) with cyclohexane (2b) to further investigate the performance of NiV-CN materials. As shown in Table 2 , different light sources were used to investigate the influence on the photocatalytic activity. When a 300 W Xe lamp was used as the light source, the yield of 3b was 99 % (Table 2, entry 1). To our delight, after testing different wavelengths of LED lights (Figure S13), the yield of product 3b can reach 94 % under 450 nm wavelength irradiation, which is slightly decreased compared to the Xe lamp irradiation conditions (Table 2, entry 2). The yield of 3b only 43 % in the presence of 370 nm LED lamp, even extended the reaction time to 24 h (Table 2, entry 3). In addition, the control experiments reveal that the importance of photocatalyst and light irradiation is highlighted, because the product of 3b was not obtained in the absence of light source or photocatalyst (Table 2, entries 4–6). When g-C3N4, V-CN, and Ni-CN were utilized as photocatalysts under identical conditions, the yields of product 3b were reduced to 57 %, 61 %, and 70 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 7–9). In contrast, as evident from entry 2 of Table 2, the yield of product 3b increased to 94 % under NiV-CN catalyst conditions, suggesting a pronounced synergistic interaction between the dual-metal ions (Ni2+ and V5+) in facilitating the reaction. In addition, the importance of K2S2O8 and HCl was also investigated. The yield of 3b was 15 % and 10 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 10–11). 3.3 Photocatalytic Minisci-type CCRs mechanism In order to investigate the stability of NiV-CN composites, the centrifuged NiV-CN was used in a new reaction system. After recycling three times, the yield of 3b can still maintain 88 % (Figure S12). The stability of NiV-CN after three cycles was further evaluated by IR, PXRD, XPS, and ICP-OES/MS (Figure S10-11). The results showed that the characterization data of IR, PXRD, XPS, and ICP-OES/MS of NiV-CN after three cycles matched well with those of the pristine NiV-CN, demonstrating the excellent stability of the catalyst. In order to further underlying mechanism of the Minisci-type CCRs process, a series of control experiments were conducted. The results show that the yield of 3b is only 15 % under the atmospheric conditions (air), indicating the CCRs unable to effectively formation under the active oxygen (Table 2, entry 10). Using the 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl piperidin-1-oxyl (TEMPO) as a radical scavenger, the desired product 3b was suppressed, thus indicating a radical process in the reaction. The cyclohexane CCRs was confirmed by the TEMPO trapped product 3bb, which was detected by the high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) (Scheme S1 a). In addition, two parallel reactions using cyclohexane and cyclohexane-d as substrates were conducted under optimal conditions, respectively (Scheme S1b). The kinetic isotope effect (KIE) (KH/KD = 2.6) reveals that the formation CCRs from cyclohexane by the cleavage of the C–H bond was probably the rate-determining step in the reaction. Considering that the sulphate radical (SO4 •-) may be produced under light irradiation in the presence of K2S2O8. We introduced p-benzoquinone (PBQ) as a SO4 •- scavenger to investigate its behavior. The desired product 3b was reduced to 14 %, indicating that SO4 •- is probably an important reactive radical in the Minisci-type CCRs process (Fig. 3C). In addition, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was employed to confirm the formation of SO4 •- during the photocatalysis process. In the presence of the spin-trapping reagent 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO), features of the EPR signal for the DMPO–SO4 •- was observed (Fig. 3D) [97]. These results reveal that the important of SO4 •- under the experimental conditions. Furthermore, fluorescence quenching experiments (Fig. 3E-F) show that the K2S2O8 can effectively quench the excited state of NiV-CN, which indicates that the interaction between the nickel-vanadium nanoparticle and K2S2O8. Additionally, with AgNO3 and ammonium oxalate (AO) serving as an electron scavenger and a hole scavenger, respectively, a significant decrease in the yield of 3b to less than 5 % and 23 % was observed, indicating the importance of photogenerated electrons (e-) and holes (h+). Based on the mechanistic studies and precedents in the literature, a plausible mechanism for this Minisci-type CCRs process can be proposed. As depicted in Scheme 1, upon illumination, the generation of holes (h+) and electrons (e-) occurs predominantly in the valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB), respectively, within the NiV-CN material. Based on the comprehensive analysis of photocurrent measurements and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), it is observed that, within the NiV-CN composite, electrons (e-) originating from the conduction band (CB) of NiV-CN undergo an efficient transfer process to the NiV nanoparticles. Subsequently, a single electron transfer (SET) process occurs from NiV nanoparticles, leading to the activation of K2S2O8 and the formation of a sulfate radical (SO4 •-) (detected by EPR). The SO4 •- radical then abstracts a hydrogen atom from cyclohexane 2b, generating cyclohexane radical 4 (confirmed by the TEMPO trapped product 3bb). Then, the amine radical cation intermediate 6 is formed through the addition of the protonated heteroarene 5 by the cyclohexane radical 4. The amine radical cation intermediate 6 loses a proton to obtain the α-amino radical 7. Subsequently, the protonated product 8 was obtained through the SET process mediated by the VB of NiV-CN. Encouraged by the positive results and our further insights into the applicability of NiV-CN in Minisci-type CCRs reactions, we conducted an investigation into the performance of NiV-CN in reactions involving quinoline derivatives, isoquinoline derivatives, benzothiazole, O-heterocycles, cycloalkanes, and adamantane as substrates (Table 3 ). A wide array of cycloalkanes and O-heterocycles, including cyclopentane, cyclohexane, cycloheptane, cyclooctane, adamantane, tetrahydrofuran, tetrahydropyran, and 1,4-Dioxane, reacted with 4-methylquinoline at the most electron-poor positions, giving the corresponding products 3a-3h in yields ranging from 65 % to 94 %. The reaction of 2- and 4-chloro-substituted quinolines with cyclohexane afforded 68 % and 82 % yields, respectively (3i-3j). In addition, the isoquinoline derivatives and benzothiazole reacted with cycloalkanes also obtained the corresponding products 3 k-3q in moderate to good yields. The possible reason for the slightly greater steric hindrance at the 1-position of isoquinoline compared to that at the 2-position of 4-methylquinoline is that it affects the yield of isoquinoline. Furthermore, when using the two possible sites of quinoline and 7,8-benzoquinoline as substrate with cycloalkanes can afford the bisalkylation products as the major product in moderate to good yields. 4 Conclusion In summary, a simple hydrothermal method was employed to synthesis a self-assembled photocatalyst, consisting of decavanadate and Ni(HCO3)2 nanoparticles anchored on carbon nitride. This NiV-CN composite significantly enhances the photocatalytic performance of the Minisci-type CCRs process, attaining yields of up to 99 % under Xe lamp irradiation and 94 % under blue LED (450 nm) illumination, respectively. In addition, the NiV-CN composite exhibits good tolerance to a range of substrates, including quinoline, isoquinoline, benzothiazole, cycloalkane, and adamantane, and demonstrates high stability with no significant influence on catalytic activity after three cycles. Fluorescence quenching, radical-trapping experiments, EPR analysis, and KIE studies have elucidated that the reaction mechanism involves the evolution of an active sulfate radical-induced CCRs process to achieve C–H alkylation of N-heteroarenes. This work provides valuable insights into the hydrothermal method for the self-assembly of nanoparticles, offering new opportunities for photocatalytic carbon-centered radicals (CCRs) processes. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalysis Minisci-type reactions involving carbon-centered radicals (CCRs) have emerged as a hot and significant topic in the field of organic synthesis chemistry. Herein, we present a nickel-vanadium nanoparticle anchored on carbon nitride catalyst (NiV-CN) and persulfate as a hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) precursor. This catalyst enables the photocatalytic Minisci-type CCR alkylation. The nickel-vanadium nanoparticles are synthesized via electrostatic attraction between [V10O28]6− anions and Ni(HCO3)2, with in situ self-assembly occurring during the hydrothermal process. In the model reaction of 4-methylquinoline with cyclohexane, the NiV-CN catalyst showed high stability, without significant loss its catalytic activity after three cycles. The CCRs was extended to cycloalkanes, adamantanes, and cyclic ethers, which react with quinoline, isoquinoline, and benzothiazole to provide the corresponding products in moderate to excellent yields. Mechanism studies indicate that nickel-vanadium nanoparticles play a crucial role in the formation process of carbon-centered radicals by activating the persulfate precursor into sulfate radicals under visible-light irradiation.

coredata.dc:title: Self-assembly of decavanadate and Ni(HCO3)2 into nanoparticles anchored on carbon nitride for efficient photocatalytic Minisci-type alkylation
